verses.text: After this, Jesus walked in Galilee. He would not go about in Judea because the Jews were seeking to kill him.
verses.comment: John emphasizes the rising opposition to Jesus and His cautious movement in Galilee, fulfilling the pattern of God's providence and timing.

verses.text: Now the Jewish Feast of Booths was near.
verses.comment: The Feast of Booths (Tabernacles) was a major Jewish festival commemorating Israel's sojourning in the wilderness. This context underlines the theme of God's presence among His people.

verses.text: So his brothers said to him, 'Leave here and go to Judea, so that your disciples also may see the works you are doing.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ brothers, not yet believing, misunderstood His mission and urged a public display.

verses.text: 'For no one works in secret if he seeks to be known openly. If you do these things, show yourself to the world.'
verses.comment: Their suggestion reflects earthly thinking: glory through visibility rather than through humility and obedience to God's will.

verses.text: For not even his brothers believed in him.
verses.comment: This underlines John’s theme of unbelief even among those closest to Jesus. Some early church traditions suggest at least some of these brothers came to faith after the resurrection (Acts 1:14).

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'My time has not yet come, but your time is always here.'
verses.comment: Jesus operates according to the Father’s appointed time, a major theme in John's Gospel.

verses.text: The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify about it that its works are evil.
verses.comment: Jesus' call for repentance and truth provoked opposition. See also 1 John 3:13.

verses.text: 'You go up to the feast. I am not going up to this feast now, for my time has not yet fully come.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ obedience to the divine plan is emphasized. Note that some ancient manuscripts read, 'I am not yet going up.'

verses.text: After saying this, he remained in Galilee.
verses.comment: Jesus stays back, modeling humility and detachment from human expectations.

verses.text: But after his brothers had gone up to the feast, then he also went up, not publicly but in secret.
verses.comment: Jesus journeys according to divine wisdom, not seeking sensationalism.

verses.text: The Jews were looking for him at the feast and saying, 'Where is he?'
verses.comment: His reputation causes expectation—even among opponents.

verses.text: And there was much murmuring about him among the crowds. Some said, 'He is a good man.' Others said, 'No, he leads the people astray.'
verses.comment: Early division of opinion about Jesus has continued throughout history and foreshadows the need for authoritative clarification.

verses.text: Yet no one spoke openly of him for fear of the Jews.
verses.comment: Fear of religious authorities stifles open discussion—hinting at later conflicts over professing faith openly.

verses.text: About the middle of the feast Jesus went up into the temple and began teaching.
verses.comment: Jesus’ public teaching in the Temple demonstrates His authority over Israel’s worship and doctrine.

verses.text: The Jews marveled, saying, 'How is it that this man has learning, when he has never studied?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ knowledge comes directly from God, not human schooling, pointing to the divine source of His doctrine.

verses.text: So Jesus answered them, 'My teaching is not mine, but his who sent me.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims direct authority from the Father, underscoring His divine mission and unity with the Father.

verses.text: If anyone wills to do his will, he will know whether the teaching is from God or whether I am speaking on my own authority.
verses.comment: Those open to God’s will can discern truth—implying the necessity of humility and openness to guidance beyond private interpretation.

verses.text: The one who speaks on his own authority seeks his own glory; but the one who seeks the glory of him who sent him is true, and there is no unrighteousness in him.
verses.comment: Jesus places all glory on the Father. This humility is a mark of a true messenger.

verses.text: 'Has not Moses given you the law? Yet none of you keeps the law. Why do you seek to kill me?'
verses.comment: Jesus points to the failure to keep the law fully, indicating its fulfillment demands more than external compliance.

verses.text: The crowd answered, 'You have a demon! Who is seeking to kill you?'
verses.comment: The accusation reveals misunderstanding and spiritual blindness among the people.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'I did one work, and you all marvel at it.'
verses.comment: Refers to the healing at Bethesda (John 5), which provoked controversy about the Sabbath.

verses.text: Moses gave you circumcision (not that it is from Moses, but from the fathers), and you circumcise a man on the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Contradiction exposed: Sabbath law yields to greater obligations—hinting that the law serves something beyond itself.

verses.text: If on the Sabbath a man receives circumcision so that the law of Moses may not be broken, are you angry with me because I made an entire man well on the Sabbath?
verses.comment: Jesus shows that mercy fulfills the law, a principle at the heart of sacramental life, which triumphs over legalistic readings.

verses.text: Do not judge by appearance, but judge with right judgment.'
verses.comment: True judgment is spiritual, not merely by external standards—a warning against superficial religion.

verses.text: Some of the people of Jerusalem therefore said, 'Is not this the man whom they seek to kill?'
verses.comment: Public awareness grows of the mounting opposition to Jesus.

verses.text: And here he is, speaking openly, and they say nothing to him! Can it be that the rulers really know that this is the Christ?
verses.comment: Confusion about Jesus’ identity; people sense a disconnect between the leaders and truth.

verses.text: But we know where this man comes from, but when the Christ appears, no one will know where he comes from.'
verses.comment: A theological misunderstanding: Old Testament points to Bethlehem as Messiah’s origin, yet also affirms His mysterious divine origin.

verses.text: So Jesus proclaimed, as he taught in the temple, 'You know me, and you know where I come from. But I have not come on my own authority. He who sent me is true, and you do not know him.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ heavenly origin is asserted, which is a veiled claim to divinity, surpassing mere human ancestry.

verses.text: I know him, for I come from him, and he sent me.'
verses.comment: Jesus speaks from unique intimacy with God, another mark of His divine identity.

verses.text: So they were seeking to arrest him, but no one laid a hand on him, because his hour had not yet come.
verses.comment: Divine providence preserves Jesus for His appointed time of sacrifice, reinforcing God's control over redemptive history.

verses.text: Yet many of the crowd believed in him and said, 'When the Christ appears, will he do more signs than this man has done?'
verses.comment: Signs point to Jesus’ messiahship, an important factor in faith and the recognition of divinely approved authority.

verses.text: The Pharisees heard the crowd muttering these things about him, and the chief priests and the Pharisees sent officers to arrest him.
verses.comment: Religious leaders’ authority was threatened, prompting official action against Jesus.

verses.text: Then Jesus said, 'I will be with you a little longer, and then I am going to him who sent me.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to His coming departure and return to the Father—a veiled reference to His ascension.

verses.text: You will seek me and will not find me. Where I am, you cannot come.'
verses.comment: A warning to those rejecting Him—separation from the presence of Christ is judgment.

verses.text: The Jews said to one another, 'Where does this man intend to go that we will not find him? Does he intend to go to the Dispersion among the Greeks and teach the Greeks?'
verses.comment: They misunderstand, thinking only in earthly terms, unable to see the spiritual meaning.

verses.text: What does he mean by saying, 'You will seek me and will not find me, and where I am you cannot come'?'
verses.comment: Their questioning highlights the confusion that arises apart from spiritual insight.

verses.text: On the last day of the feast, the great day, Jesus stood up and cried out, 'If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink.'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as the source of spiritual life, fulfilling Old Testament imagery of living water.

verses.text: Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, 'Out of his heart will flow rivers of living water.'
verses.comment: This promise ultimately finds fulfillment in the outpouring of the Holy Spirit through Jesus (see the next verse).

verses.text: Now he said this about the Spirit, whom those who believed in him were to receive; for as yet the Spirit had not been given, because Jesus was not yet glorified.
verses.comment: Receiving the Spirit is connected to faith in Christ and His glorification—His passion, resurrection, and ascension inaugurate this gift. See Prov. 1:23 for Old Testament parallels.

verses.text: When they heard these words, some of the people said, 'This really is the Prophet.'
verses.comment: 'The Prophet' refers to the one foretold by Moses, a sign of high messianic expectation.

verses.text: Others said, 'This is the Christ.' But some said, 'Is the Christ to come from Galilee?'
verses.comment: Points to misunderstanding of prophecy: Messiah’s true origins would fulfill Scripture in ways not recognized by all.

verses.text: 'Has not the Scripture said that the Christ comes from the offspring of David, and comes from Bethlehem, the village where David was?'
verses.comment: Points to Messianic prophecy about David’s line and Bethlehem (see also Matthew 2:1, Luke 2:4).

verses.text: So there was a division among the people over him.
verses.comment: Jesus as a sign of contradiction foreshadowed by Simeon (Luke 2:34)—faith in Him unites and divides.

verses.text: Some of them wanted to arrest him, but no one laid hands on him.
verses.comment: Again, Jesus is protected by the Father's will till His predestined hour.

verses.text: Then the officers came to the chief priests and Pharisees, who said to them, 'Why did you not bring him?'
verses.comment: Incidents here demonstrate Jesus’ extraordinary authority and the inability of human force alone to prevail against Him.

verses.text: The officers answered, 'No one ever spoke like this man!'
verses.comment: Jesus’ words display transcendent authority and wisdom beyond mere teaching.

verses.text: The Pharisees answered them, 'Have you also been deceived?'
verses.comment: Leaders scorn the officers for being swayed—contrasting openness to authority versus closed rigidity.

verses.text: 'Have any of the rulers or the Pharisees believed in him?'
verses.comment: A warning against elitism—the leaders assume authority but misjudge the truth.

verses.text: But this crowd that does not know the law is accursed.'
verses.comment: Religious leaders insult those less educated, showing a contrast between external formality and living faith.

verses.text: Nicodemus, who had gone to him before, and who was one of them, said to them,
verses.comment: Nicodemus reappears as a voice for fairness, signifying sincere religious inquiry even within leadership.

verses.text: 'Does our law judge a man without first giving him a hearing and learning what he does?'
verses.comment: Nicodemus reminds them of due process, a principle rooted in the justice and order God sets for His people.

verses.text: They replied, 'Are you from Galilee too? Search and see that no prophet arises from Galilee.'
verses.comment: Their response is misguided—prophets like Jonah came from Galilee, displaying the leaders’ bias and incomplete knowledge.

verses.text: Then each went to his own house.
verses.comment: Division unresolved, each withdraws—the narrative tension remains, pointing to the need for unity under revealed truth.
